questions.text: Which of the coagulation factor decreases in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state, with all the coagulation factors increasing except Factor 11 and 13.

Increase during pregnancy

  • Hemoglobin mass
  • Total plasma protein
  • Globulin
  • Leucocytes(neutrophilic leucocytosis)
  • Fibrinogen
  • Factors II, VII, VIII, IX, X
  • Insulin

Lipids, lipoproteins(LDL and HDL) and apolipoproteins

  • Serum Transferrin and
  • C-reactive protein
  • Placenta phosphatase
  • Total alkaline phosphatase

Decrease during pregnancy

  • Hemoglobin concentration
  • Factor XI and XIII
  • All parameters of iron metabolism except TIBC and transferrin
  • Serum blood urea nitrogen
    • Serum Na / K / Ca / Mg / I2

Albumin

  • Platelets

questions.text:
Hormonal parameters seen in cases of Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism are:
1. Low LH, Low FSH
2. Low Testosterone
3. Low Prolactin levels
4. Oligospermia
5. Low LH, High FSH
questions.solution:
Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism: Defect is at the level of hypothalamus or pituitary. FSH level low < 10 m IU/ml

Hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism : Defect is at the level of testes leading to low testosterone levels and high FSH,LH levels.


DOC for treating hypogonadotropic hypogonadism = Testosterone replacement therapy in order to promote secondary sexual characteristics and external genitalia.

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly associated with Kallman syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Kallmann syndrome is one of the causes of hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism that's characterized by absent or delayed puberty and a lack or loss of sense of smell.
  • There is defective migration of GnRH neurons from olfactory placode to hypothalamus leading to features of hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism(Low LH, FSH and low Estrogen)and anosmia.
  • Inheritance: Most commonly X linked
  • Other features include: Colour blindness, midline facial defects, renal anomalies and syndactyly
  • Findings in Kallman syndrome are summarized in the image shown below:

Kallmann syndrome is also associated with midline facial anomalies such as cleft palate, unilateral renal agenesis, cerebellar ataxia, epilepsy, neurosensory hearing loss, and synkinesis (mirror movements of the hands).

questions.text: Which of the following is not cost-effective regular screening procedure advised for pregnant women?
questions.solution:
Any pregnant female is advised to undergo the following routine investigations in her 1st antenatal visit so as to detect any high risk pregnancies:

  • Blood group, Rh typing
  • Urinalysis: Dipstick method
  • CBC: 1st visit and then repeat at 24-28 weeks
  • Blood sugar: 1st visit and then repeat at 24-28 weeks
  • TSH levels

CDC also recommends that all pregnant women get tested for HIV, hepatitis B virus(HBV), hepatitis C virus(HCV) and syphilis(VDRL) during each pregnancy. Screening is necessary to access medical services for HCV infection and treatment to prevent transmission of HIV, HBV and syphilis to the infant.

Echo is not a routine screening procedure. Fetal echo is done in cases of:

  • Known case of congenital heart disease in parents
  • History of pre gestational diabetes or high levels of HBA1C(risk of CVBS anomalies)
  • Monochorionic twins

Other tests done are:

  • Dating scan
  • NT NB scan , Dual markers---- 11-13 wks
  • Level 2 scan/anomaly scan---- 18-20 wks

questions.text: Preeclampsia, which is incorrect
questions.solution:
Remember:

In preeclampsia

  • Antiangiogenic factors and vasoconstrictors increases
  • Angiogenic factors and vasodilators decreases
  • Antiangiogenic factors like SFLT-1, S-Endoglein increases
  • Vasoconstrictors like TxA2, Endothelin increases
  • Angiogenic factors like VEGF, PlGF decreases
  • Vasodilators like PGI2, NO decreases
  • Also PGI2:TxA2 ratio decreases

Tests to predict preeclampsia

Microalbuminuria - The test is not very reliable.

Hyperhomocysteinemia: In woman with preclampsia levels of homocysteine are increased 3-4 fold timesat midpregnancy.

Uric acid excretion is decreased in women with preeclampsia. Hyperuricemia is one of the earliest

Manifestation of preeclampsia

Plasma uric acid values > 5.9 mg/dl at 24 weeks have a positive predictive value for preeclampsia.

Mean arterial Pressure in second trimester

if mean arterial pressure is ≥ 90 mmHg in second trimester chances of developing preeclampsia increase.

Urinary Calcium

Urinary calcium < 12 mg /dl in 24 hrs. indicate impending preeclampsia (Preeclampsia is associated with hypocalciuria)

Angiotensin sensitivity test

It is based on the fact that women destined to develop preeclampsia lose their refractoriness to angiotensin between 28-32 weeks

If a pressure response occurs with <8 ng/kg/min of infused angiotensin, 90% are likely to develop pre-eclampsia.

Roll over test

The test is done at 28-32 weeks.

It measures angiotensin sensitivity in susceptibles when they lie supine

The woman is turned from the left lateral to the supine position

If there is an increase in the diastolic blood pressure by 20 mm or more, the test is considered positive

Doppler ultrasound

Presence of diastolic notch between 22-24 weeks by Doppler velocimetry in the uterine artery predicts the development of preeclampsia.

It is probably the best available test.

  • Fibronectin - It is released from endothelial cells following endothelial

Patients with preeclampsia have elevated levels of plasma fibronectin, a glycoprotein.

Fetal DNA - Identification of fetal DNA in maternal serum also predicts preeclampsia

choices.text: Mgso4 causes uterine relaxation but dose dependant
Mgso4 in renal failure loading dose can be given but maintenance dose should be adjusted based on renal function
Mgso4 in renal failure loading dose can be given but maintenance dose should be adjusted based on renal function

questions.text: Mgso4 false statement?
questions.solution:
• MgSO₄ is the drug of choice for prevention and management of convulsions in eclampsia.
  • MgSO4 controls seizures but does not control hypertension.
  • MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic for uterine relaxation but this action is dose dependent.(Option A) The tocolytic of choice is Nifedipine.
  • MgSO4 acts as a neuroprotective agent and hence controls seizure in eclamptic patient and also used in preterm babies if born before 32 weeks POG.(Option D)

Mechanism of action:

  • It decreases the acetylcholine release from the nerve endings and decreases the sensitivity of motor end plate to Ach.
  • Blocks the calcium channel and decreases intracranial

Regimens for MgSO₄:

Therapeutic range - 4 to 7 mEq/L

  • There is a narrow range at which therapeutic effect and toxic effects of Magnesium occurs, therefore monitoring for magnesium toxicity is very important.
  • In patients with renal failure, Loading dose of MgSO4 can be given but the maintenance dose needs to be adjusted based on renal function(Option B)

Monitoring for magnesium toxicity

  • Urine output should be at least 30 ml/hr
  • Deep tendon reflexes (Patellar reflex) should be present
  • Respiration rate should be more than 14/min.
  • Pulse oximetry should be ³ 96%

Remember

Repeat injection are given only if:

  • Knee jerks are present
  • Urine output > 30 ml/hour
  • Respiratory rate ³ 14/min

MgS04 loading dose depends on volume of distribution whereas maintenance dose depends on clearance of the drug.

MgS04 in renal failure: loading dose can be given but maintenance dose should be adjusted based on renal function.

choices.text: Change to oral antibiotics when afebrile
Establish U/O atleast 50 ml/hr with IV crystalloids
Discharge when afebrile for 48 hrs, consider antimicrobials for 5 days

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding pyelonephritis in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Approach for pyelonephritis in pregnancy:

  • All patients should be hospitalised(Option A)
  • Investigations: Urine and blood culture, CBC, Sr.Creatinine, Sr.Electrolytes
  • Monitor the vitals and urine output: Try to maintain urine output >= 50 ml/hr using IV Crystalloids(Option C)
  • Most common organism implicated is E. coli
  • Treatment: DOC IV Ampicillin or Cefazolin or Ceftriaxone
  • Change to oral antibiotics once the patient is afebrile , continue for 7-10 days(Option B)
  • Discharge once the patient is afebrile for 24 hrs

questions.text: Which of the following constitutes Modified BPP?
questions.solution:
• The components of modified Biophysical profile are:
    • NST+AFI

Following are the components of Biophysical profile(BPP):

Mnemonic: Remember it as "TBMAN"

Fetal Tone, Fetal Breathing, Fetal Movements, AFI & NST

questions.text: A woman has been taking Tamoxifen after mastectomy for breast cancer. How long should the couple wait before planning pregnancy afyter stopping Tamoxifen?
questions.solution:
To avoid the risk of fetal malformation, pregnancy is contraindicated during tamoxifen treatment and up to 3 months after its interruption.

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator(SERM).

Adverse effects of Tamoxifen:

  • Teratogenicity
  • DES like syndrome

Women having treatment for breast cancer (including the hormone treatment tamoxifen) are recommended to use non-hormonal methods of contraception, such as condoms, Femidoms or a diaphragm. It may also be possible to use a coil (IUD or intrauterine device).

choices.text: Genetic counselling for breast cancer testing

questions.text: A 37-year-old nulliparous female having regular intercourse is on OCPs Mother had breast cancer at 50 years of age-Sister had cancer at 40 years of age. What will you advise as next step?
questions.solution:
• A family history of breast cancer is a well-established risk factor for the development of the disease and hence familiar cancer syndromes should be considered.
  • Although any family history of breast cancer increases a woman's overall relative risk, women with a first-degree relative who has been affected by the disease are at approximately a twofold increased risk of developing breast cancer compared to the general population.
  • Approximately 5% to 10% of breast cancers have a known inherited basis associated with mutations in high- and low-penetrance genes. The most well-studied mutations are the BRCA1 (chromosome 17q21) and BRCA2 (chromosome 13q12-13) gene deletions.
  • Genetic testing is available and should be considered if there is a high likelihood that the results will be positive and used to influence decisions regarding the clinical management of the care of the patient and her family.

Option A,B,D are all done later but genetic screening is the first step in this case.

questions.text: Vas deferens and seminal vesicles are absent in:
questions.solution:
CBAVD(Congenital bilateral absence of seminal vesicles and vas deferens) is seen in Cystic fibrosis and is a cause of post testicular/obstructive azoospermia and absence of fructose in semen.

Typical hormone testing reveals: Normal FSH, LH, Testosterone levels

The next step of evaluation is genetic analysis for CFTR gene.

Other options are not related.

questions.text: High risk HPV does not cause
questions.solution:
HPV high risk subtypes(HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58) can cause- cervical/vaginal and vulval cancer in females and oral,anal,penile and nasopharyngeal cancer in males.

HPV low risk subtypes(HPV 6,11) can cause genital warts(Condyloma Acuminata), recurrent laryngeal papilloma, inverted papilloma.

questions.text: By giving 5 alpha reductase inhibitors, which of the following changes are observed. Mark the correct option.
questions.solution:
Testosterone----àDihydrotestosterone (This reaction is mediated by the enzyme 5 alpha reductase)

So, if 5 alpha reductase is inhibited,

  • Testosterone levels rise(Option C ruled out)
  • DHT levels fall
  • As a result of negative feedback of testosterone, LH,FSH levels fall(Option B ruled out)
  • No effect on Prolactin levels(Option D ruled out)

5-ARIs act to reduce the serum and intraprostatic DHT concentration, thereby causing involution of the prostatic epithelium and slowing the progression of BPH. The efficacy of both finasteride and dutasteride(5 alpha reductase inhibitors) in reducing DHT has been demonstrated in a number of studies.

questions.text: Kassowitz rule is related to?
questions.solution:
DIDAY-KASSOWITZ LAW (1876) - If a woman with untreated syphilis has a series of pregnancies, the likelihood of infection of the fetus in later pregnancies becomes less.

In other words, in cases of syphilis, the greater the duration between the infection of the mother and conception, the better the outcome of the infant. Features of a better outcome include less chance of stillbirths and of developing congenital syphilis.

Thus, in successive pregnancies, she may have miscarriage at the 5thmonth, next occasion-stillbirth at the 8thmonth, next, birth of an infant with congenital syphilis who dies within a few weeks followed by birth of 2 or 3 infants with congenital syphilis who survive, finally 1 or more healthy children may be born.

questions.text: Type of cerclage done in a non-pregnant patient with cervical incompetence?
questions.solution:
The purpose of the Lash and Lash operation is to correct the defect in the cervical wall and restore competence to the cervix, thereby allowing gestation to proceed to term.

  1. Lash and Lash operation is a pervaginal procedure done in non pregnant females
  2. Benson Durfee is an abdominal cerclage procedure that can be done oin bothe pregnant as well as non pregnant females.
  3. Wurms cerclage is an emergency cerclage procedure done during pregnancy

Still, Laparoscopic cerclage is the most preferred operative procedure in non pregnant females.

choices.text: Contractions 8 Contractions in 60 mins with cervical changes

questions.text: Not a criterion for preterm labour
questions.solution:
Posterior cervix is an unfavourable factor for labour and hence this is easily ruled out.

Diagnostic criteria of preterm labour:

  • Currently, cervical dilatation >=3 cm is considered as a criterion
  • Cervical length <2 cm
  • Cervical length 2-3 cm with positive fetal Fibronectin
  • Position of cervix hasn't been described in the criteria for preterm labor

Only contraction with no cervical changes is called as Threatened preterm labor

Risk factors for preterm labor:

  1. H/O previous preterm labor
  2. In utero exposure to DES
  3. Cervical surgery like cone biopsy, LLETZ, Laser ablation and

Note: Punch biopsy, Laser vaporisation and cryotherapy have not been associated with preterm birth.

  1. Obstetrical trauma to cervix during labor or delivery including spontaneous labor, forceps and vacuum delivery and cesarean section.
  2. Uterine overdistension as in multifetal pregnancy,
  3. Multiple dilation and evacuation
  4. Infections like bacterial vaginosis, asymptomatic
  5. Connective tissue disorders-Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Marfan's syndrome
  6. Preterm premature rupture of membranes
  7. Uterine anomalies - unicornuate

choices.text: Elective LSCS has no effects on reducing incidence of brachial plexus injury
GDM female can use insulin on the night before and on morning of IOL
In active labour, if RBS is <70 mg/dl, 5% dextrose is given
Capillary blood glucose are maintained at FBS: 95 mg/dl and PPBS: 120 mg/dl

questions.text: About Diabetes mellitus in pregnancy management, false statement is
questions.solution:
Morning dose of insulin is skipped on the day of labour

Antepartum Management

  • Diet: Medical nutrition therapy (MNT): It is the cornerstone of treatment of diabetes in Caloric requirement is 25-35 kcal/kg body weight/ day according to body mass index. It is advisable to take 3 major and 3 minor meals so that there is no intermittent hypoglycemia and still ideal blood sugars are maintained.

Diet composition should be 45% of carbohydrates, 30% proteins and 25% fats

  • Excercise :Planned physical activity for 30 minutes/day is recommended.

Metabolic Goals during Pregnancy:

  • Premeal value- 70-90 mg/dl > (95 mg/dl)
  • Postmeal 1 hr PP = < 148 mg/dl, 2 hr PP < 120 mg/dl
  • HbA1c <6%.
  • If these goals are not achieved patient should be put on
  • Oral hypoglycemics are not advised during pregnancy as they can cross the placenta and cause fetal hypo- glycaemia.The only oral hypoglycemic drug approved for use in pregnancy is Glyburide and metformin.

Diet and exercise should be continued for at least 2-3 weeks with the aim to achieve the following metabolic goals.

  • Insulin: is the drug of choice for management of DM/GDM in pregnancy as it does not cross the placenta.

-Patient should be advised self checking of Glucose.

Indication for starting insulin in pregnancy:

  • If FBS is more than 95 mg/dL or if 1 hour postprandial value is more than 140 mg/dL or 2 hour postprandial value is more than 120 mg/dL.
  • Dose = 7 to 1 units per kg/day in divided doses.
  • Rapid acting insulin NPH (aspart and lispro), and intermediate acting insulin are safe in The total daily requirement of insulin = 2/3 in morning + 1/3 at Night such that
  • Morning dose = 2/3 NPH + 1/3 short acting
  • Pre dinner dose = ½ NPH + ½ short acting

Intrapartum Management

Time of delivery

  • Low risk patients-wait for spontaneous labor till maximum 40 weeks
  • High risk patients-38 weeks- induce labor as IUD occurs mostly in last 2 weeks of pregnancy.
  • Mode of delivery -vaginal delivery.(Option A)

Indications of Elective LSCS in GDM Patients

  • Macrosomia with weight > 5 kg (for predicting macrosomia, shoulder width > 14 cm, EFW > 4.5 kg on ultrasound)
  • Demonstrable fetal compromise (Severe IUGR)
  • Bad obstetric history
  • Other obstetric indications
  • Elderly primigravida

Note:

  • Suspected macrosomia is not a C/I for VBAC.
  • Insulin requirement decrease during labor and since patient is on liquid diet-insulin is stopped during labour

Precautions During Caesarean:

Elective caesarean for macrosomia is recommended in a diabetic pregnancy if the estimated fetal weight is .4.5kg (ACOG).

  • Anaesthetist must be consulted prior to elective surgery.
  • After appropriate consent and blood availability, a light meal and night dose of insulin are given.
  • Elective section of a diabetic patient should preferably be performed as the first case in the morning as the patient is fasting and also there is availability of all the necessary personnel.
  • Morning insulin dose is omitted and fasting glucose level done.
  • If required sliding scale of insulin can be started and continued in the postoperative period.
  • Severely obese may require thromboprophylaxis.

Postpartum Management

Revaluation of glycemic status using 75 g oral GTT at 6 to 12 weeks postpartum.

questions.text:
From adluminal to luminal side, arrange the following series of events in spermatogenesis:
1. Myoepithelial cells
2. Spermatogonia
3. Primary spermatocyte
4. Secondary Spermatocyte
5.Spermatid
questions.solution:
Myoepithelial cells are usually found in glandular epithelium as a thin layer above the basement membrane but normally beneath the luminal cells. They are present in the sweat glands, mammary glands, lacrimal glands and in salivary glands. Myoepithelial cells are stellate-shaped and also known as basket cells.

Myoepithelial cells are attached to the luminal cells and control many aspects of luminal functions. They regulate the flow of fluid and control the entry and exit of nutrients, electrolytes and other growth factors.

From adluminal to luminal side:

  • Myoepithelial cells
  • Spermatogonia
  • Primary spermatocyte
  • Secondary spermatocyte
  • Spermatids

Reference: ncbi.nlm.nih.gov.
